occurrences.line_text: Therefore a read Sir, if thou haue a loue.
Be thou faire Britomart, whose prayse I write,
But of all wisedome be thou precedent,
Thou in dull corners doest thy selfe inclose,
Ioy thereof haue thou and eternall blis.
But if thou may with reason yet represse
Till thou in open field adowne be smot.
Thou doest effect in destined descents,
Shew'dst thou, then in this royall Maid of yore,
From whose two loynes thou afterwards did rayse
Thou haue it lastly brought vnto her Excellence.
And if thou euer happen that same way
But dare thou not, I charge, in any cace,
And brasen Caudrons thou shalt rombling heare,
Thou her afford, full shortly I her dead shall see.
And sayd, Sith then thou knowest all our griefe,
(For what doest not thou know?) of grace I pray,
But read (said Glauce) thou Magitian
To this his natiue soyle thou backe shalt bring,
Thou then shalt make, t'increase thy louers pray.
If ay more goodly creature thou didst see;
Thou God of winds, that raignest in the seas,
I read thee soone retyre, whiles thou hast might,
Now lyest thou of life and honor reft;
Now lyest thou a lumpe of earth forlorne,
Night thou foule Mother of annoyance sad,
Of all the Gods) where thou vngratious,
Thou art the root and nurse of bitter cares,
In stead of rest thou lendest rayling teares,
In stead of sleepe thou sendest troublous feares,
So from the wearie spirit thou doest driue
For till thou tidings learne, what her betide,
Now God thee keepe, thou gentlest Squire aliue,
But both of comfort him thou shalt depriue,
And eke thy selfe of honour, which thou didst atchiue.
That thou hast shewed to me sinfull wight,
Which if thou gaine, I shalbe well apayd.
With which her soueraigne mercy thou doest quight?
But thou doest weene with villeinous despight,
Thou a meane Squire, of meeke and lowly place,
But read, thou Squyre of Dames, what vow is this,
Which thou vpon thy selfe hast lately ta'ne?
How many foundst thou such to put in thy record?
Perdy, (said Satyrane) thou Squire of Dames,
Great labour fondly hast thou hent in hand,
Dy, if thou it gainesay: I will away her beare.
Saying, Thou foolish knight, that weenst with words
Sith then (said Braggadocchio) needes thou wilt
But thou good man, sith farre in sea we bee,
But if that thou, Sir Satyran, didst weete,
Or thou, Sir Peridure, her sorie state,
For dead, I surely doubt, thou maist aread
False loue, why do men say, thou canst not see,
And to thy will abuse? Thou walkest free,
Thou seest all, yet none at all sees thee;
Said he, thou man of nought, what doest thou here,
Said he, thou man of nought, what doest thou here,
At last he thus; Thou clod of vilest clay,
Of all the passions in the mind thou vilest art.
How suffrest thou such shamefull cruelty,
Or hast thou, Lord, of good mens cause no heed?
Yet thou vile man, vile Scudamore art sound,
Dwels in thy bounteous brest? what couldst thou more,
If she were thine, and thou as now am I?
And thou, faire Phoebus, in thy colours bright
That thou bewray'dst his mothers wantonnesse,
So louedst thou the lusty Hyacinct,
So louedst thou the faire Coronis deare:
(Ah man beware, how thou those darts behold)
And to him said, Thou wicked man, whose meed
But if that thou this Dame doe presently
Do thou dred infant, Venus dearling doue,
Is weakned, then thou doest him ouerronne:
So hast thou to thy selfe false honour often wonne.
Vile hag (sayd Scudamour) why dost thou lye?
Tell what thou saw'st, maulgre who so it heares.
Whereby the name of knighthood thou dost shend,
Be thou, where euer thou do go or ryde,
Be thou, where euer thou do go or ryde,
Yet thou false Squire his fault shalt deare aby,
The open wrongs, thou doest me day by day;
Well know'st thou, whe[n] we friendship first did sweare,
Whom to thy selfe thou takest quite away?
A read thou Squire, that I the man may learne,
That none durst euer whilest thou wast aliue,
Well worthie thou to be of Ioue accurst,
That workst such wrecke on her, to whom thou dearest art.
What glorie, or what guerdon hast thou found
With which their liues thou lanchedst long afore,
So whylome didst thou to faire Florimell;
So doest thou now to her, of whom I tell,
Thou martyrest with sorow and with smart,
Vntride, is lesse then when thou shalt it try:
Till thou cam'st hither to augment our mone,
Ah dreadfull tidings which thou doest declare,
Hast thou in all this time, from him vnknowne
And when thou spredst thy mantle forth on hie,
To come where thou doest draw them with desire:
Soone as with fury thou doest them inspire,
And dayly yet thou doest the same repayre:
But thou the same for pleasure didst prepayre.
Thou art the root of all that ioyous is,
Helpe therefore, O thou sacred imp of Ioue,
But where so loose or happy that thou art,
Not so thou Squire, (he sayd) but thine I deeme
For worthy thou of her doest rightly seeme.
Thou that presum'st to weigh the world anew,
For ere thou limit what is lesse or more
In euery thing, thou oughtest first to know,
But if thou now shouldst weigh them new in pound,
Thou foolishe Elfe (said then the Gyant wroth)
The sea it selfe doest thou not plainely see
Of things vnseene how canst thou deeme aright,
Sith thou misdeem'st so much of things in sight?
In vaine therefore doest thou now take in hand,
Whose counsels depth thou canst not vnderstand,
Thou doest not know the causes, nor their courses dew.
For take thy ballaunce, if thou be so wise,
But if the weight of these thou canst not show,
For how canst thou those greater secrets know,
And to the boaster said; Thou losell base,
When they are all restor'd, thou shalt rest in disgrace.
That shield, which thou doest beare, was it indeed,
But not that arme, nor thou the man I reed,
Or shew the sweat, with which thou diddest sway
Goe thou vnto that stranger Faery Knight,
Clarin (sayd she) thou seest yond Fayry Knight,
To which if thou canst win him any way,
Which that thou mayst the better bring to pas,
From time to time, when thou it best shalt see,
That in and out thou mayst haue passage free.
With which thou canst euen Ioue himselfe to loue entise.
To thinke how this long death thou mightest disinherit.
Then why doest not, thou ill aduized man,
And try if thou by faire entreatie, can
Her dayes in warre, yet (weet thou) was not borne
Till thou haue tride againe, & tempted him more neare.
With which in case thou canst him not inuade,
When thou hast all this doen, then bring me newes
Cease thou bad newes-man, badly doest thou hide
Cease thou bad newes-man, badly doest thou hide
Thou recreant false traytor, that with lone
But with thy bloud thou shalt appease the spright
How coul[d]st thou weene, through that disguized hood,
Then shalt thou take him to thy loued fere,
Vnto the man, whom thou doest loue so deare;
And tell him for his sake thy life thou gauest.
Thus answer'd; Lewdly thou my loue deprauest,
But euen that which thou sauedst, thine still to remaine?
Whiles she alone is left, and thou here found?
And for what cause, tell if thou haue it knowne.
And turne thee soone to him, of whom thou art defyde.
Art thou the caytiue, that defyest me,
And for this Mayd, whose party thou doest take,
Now comest thou to rob my house vnmand,
Yet doubt thou not, but that some better Knight
Then thou, that shall thy treason vnderstand,
Cowherd (quoth she) were not, that thou wouldst fly,
But then aread, thou gentle chyld, wherefore
As by thy worth thou worthily hast wonne,
(Vnlesse thou in these woods thy selfe conceale,
Glad would I surely be, thou courteous Squire,
Thou brings? aie me, is this the timely ioy,
Perdy thou peasant Knight, mightst rightly reed
But as thou hast thy steed forlorne with shame,
So fare on foote till thou another gayne,
That thou for euer doe those armes forsake,
Vnlesse thou dare for thy deare Ladies sake,
His name (quoth he) if that thou list to learne,
Art thou he, traytor, that with treason vile,
Whereof thou caytiue so vnworthie art;
Yet further hast thou heaped shame to shame,
Gainst errant Knights and Ladies thou dost reare,
Whom when thou mayst, thou dost of arms despoile,
Whom when thou mayst, thou dost of arms despoile,
Yet doest thou not with manhood, but with guile
Vnlesse to me thou hether bring with speed
Now turne againe my teme thou iolly swayne,
Pype iolly shepheard, pype thou now apace
Right happy thou, that mayst them freely see:
As thou vnhappy, which them thence didst chace,
Whom by no meanes thou canst recall againe;
Then wote thou shepheard, whatsoeuer thou bee,
Then wote thou shepheard, whatsoeuer thou bee,
That all those Ladies, which thou sawest late,
But gentle Shepheard pardon thou my shame,
But read thou shepheard, read what destiny,
And liuest thou my daughter now againe?
And art thou yet aliue, whom dead I long did faine.
I better wot then you, though now too late
For though a tree I seeme, yet cold and heat me paines.
Though true as touch, though daughter of a king,
Though true as touch, though daughter of a king,
Though faire as euer liuing wight was faire,
Though nor in word nor deede ill meriting,
Though conquered now he lie on lowly land,
For the old man well knew he, though vntold,
Though greeued ghost for vengeance deepe do grone:
Could it discerne, though I the mother bee
And though good lucke prolonged hath thy date,
Though spousd, yet wanting wedlocks solemnize;
And though they faultie were, yet well he wayd,
Though false Duessa it to barre
Which though he hath polluted oft of yore,
Sometimes her staffe, though it her one leg were,
Though she thy Lady be, approch thee neare;
And though he scornd his idle vanitie,
Though otherwise it did him litle harme:
Matter of merth enough, though there were none
And all though pleasant, yet she made much more:
Therewith she sweetly smyld. They though full bent,
Though somewhat moued in his mightie hart,
And though him selfe were at the sight dismayd,
Though all the wealth, which is, or was of yore,
The God, though loth, yet was constraind t'obay,
And though they both stood stiffe, yet could not both withstond.
Full liuely is the semblaunt, though the substance dead.
Here may ye not haue entraunce, though we would:
For though they bodies seeme, yet substance from them fades.
Nor that proud towre of Troy, though richly guilt,
Right firme & strong, though somewhat they declind;
Ne yet Mathusalem, though longest liu'd;
Which though from earth it be deriued right,
Fro[m] Guendolene his wife, though alwaies faithfull prou'd.
Yet liues his memorie, though carcas sleepe in rest.
And yet though ouercome in haplesse fight,
That is our Selfe, whom though we do not see,
(Said she) and though no reason may apply
Though strange beginning had, yet fixed is
For though my loue be not so lewdly bent,
So was their fortune good, though wicked were their mind.
But wicked fortune mine, though mind be good,
For though beyond the Africk Ismaell,
And may not shrinck, though all the world do shake:
And though oft looking backward, well she vewd,
That loues his fetters, though they were of gold.
Though nought beleu'd, & entrau[n]ce late did not refuse.
And Paridell though partly discontent
Though whilome far much greater then thy fame,
Be not too bold; whereto though she did bend
Though much emmou'd, but stedfast still perseuered.
No spot of blame, though spite did oft assay
For though like withered tree, that wanteth iuyce,
That though therein himselfe he thought to pas,
Though now their acts be no where to be found,
Though for her sake they all that perill tooke,
Though sad and sorie for so heauy sight,
And there made gods, though borne of mortall berth,
Which Cambell seeing, though he could not salue,
They haue him taken captiue, though it grieue him sore.
And though some while Fortune from him withdrew,
Though knowne to few, that Arthegall he hight,
As though she wished to haue pleasd them all,
Yet did the smart remaine, though he himselfe did flee.
That though she mounted were, yet he her made
Right plaine appeard, though she it would dissemble,
For yet she may be safe though somewhat strayd;
Its best to hope the best, though of the worst affrayd.
Her second care, though in another kind;
Thine honor sau'd, though into thraldome throwne?
Though there were none her hatefull words to heare:
Though namelesse there his bodie now doth lie,
He though affide vnto a former loue,
For though Poeana were as faire as morne,
And made his Dwarfe, though with vnwilling ayd,
She, though full oft she both of them had seene
For though she were most faire, and goodly dyde,
For though sweet loue to conquer glorious be,
Though all the pillours of the one were guilt,
But I though meanest man of many moe,
Though of contrarie natures each to other:
Rich Oranochy, though but knowen late;
Ne storming Humber, though he looked stout;
And shall see Stamford, though now homely hid,
And Albany: And Eden though but small,
Though I them all according their degree,
For though their numbers do much more surmount,
Of mortall sire, though of immortall wombe,
Though vaine I see my sorrowes to vnfold,
I will them tell though vnto no man neare:
Yet though he neuer list to me relent,
And though vnto his will she giuen were,
But would some rightfull cause pretend, though rightly nought.
And though his limbs could not his bodie beare,
Though vertue then were held in highest price,
That she might win some time, though dearly bought
What though the sea with waues continuall
Which Artegall well hearing, though no more
For any death to chaunge life though most bad:
And though my land he first did winne away,
And then my loue (though now it little skill,)
Yet though him selfe did shame on womankinde
And though powre faild, her courage did accrew:
Doth seeme to be her selfe, though darkned be her light.
And though he still retyr'd, yet nathelesse
For though that he first victorie obtayned,
For though this cloud haue now me ouercast,
And, though (vnlike) they should for euer last,
Moue Radigund? who though she still haue worne
Who though desirous rather to rest mute,
Ne doffe her armes, though he her much besought.
Wherewith though wondrous wroth, and inly burning,
And her late vile reproch, though vaunted vaine,
Where though reuengefull vow she did professe,
Though nothing whole, but all to brusd and broken,
Though also those mote question'd be aright,
Though plaine she saw by all, that she did heare,
But Iustice, though her dome she doe prolong,
As by sad Belge seemes, whose wrongs though long
Though I this dearest life for her doe spend;
Is mine owne loue, though me she haue forlore,
Though darts from shore and stones they at him threw;
Which none durst breake, though many would right faine
The cursed Serpent, though she hungrily
Which though it on a lowly stalke doe bowre,
Of which though present age doe plenteous seeme,
Wilt giue thy beard, though it but little bee?
Though they enforce themselues, cannot attaine.
Which I enforst to beare though to my paine,
Let me this craue, vnworthy though of it,
(Though none more noble then is cheualrie,)
The lusty Aladine, though meaner borne,
There left on ground, though in full euill plight,
For though she were right glad, so rid to bee
Glad of that easement, though it were but small;
Whom though he saw now somewhat ouerpast,
Which though I be not wise enough to frame,
Yet he them all refusd, though thankt her as a frend.
Who though he were still in this desert wood,
And wend abrode, though feeble and forlorne,
Though many foes did him maligne therefore,
And eke his Lady, though she sickely were,
But that wylde man, whom though he oft forbad,
Though of meane parentage and kindred base,
Who though she were with wearinesse nigh dead,
Slay not that Carle, though worthy to be slaine:
That though the night did couer her disgrace,
Though meane her lot, yet higher did her mind ascend.
Which though it were a cottage clad with lome,
The fruite of ioy and blisse, though long time dearely bought.
That euen her owne Cytheron, though in it
But Calidore, though no lesse sory wight,
Arriued in this Isle though bare and blunt,
The sight of whom, though now decayd and mard,
Though not his feare; for nought may feare disswade;
Though out of course, yet hath not bene mis-sayd,
Where he slept soundly void of euill thought,
He thought haue slaine her in his fierce despight:
Eftsoones I thought her such, as she me told,
Perceiu'd my thought, and drownd in sleepie night,
By which she thought her wandring knight shold pas,
Farre be it from your thought, and fro my will,
Thought all their glorie vaine in knightly vew,
The noble hart, that harbours vertuous thought,
With beastly sin thought her to haue defilde,
Eternall prouidence exceeding thought,
And him to dust thought to haue battred quight,
And can more easily be thought, then said.
So deepe did settle in her gratious thought,
Or that your wisedome will direct my thought,
So thought I eke of him, and thinke I thought aright.
So thought I eke of him, and thinke I thought aright.
Him thought at first encounter to haue slaine,
Ne shame he thought to shunne so hideous might:
Should die vnknown, & buried be in thanklesse thought.
Dame Cï¿½lia men did her call, as thought
Himselfe to chearish, and consuming thought
Thought with his wings to stye aboue the ground;
But thought his armes to leaue, and helmet to vnlace.
He thought attonce him to haue swallowd quight,
Well mote yee thee, as well can wish your thought,
One thought their cheare too litle, th'other thought too mutch.
One thought their cheare too litle, th'other thought too mutch.
Ne thought of honour euer did assay
For such, as he him thought, or faine would bee:
Thought in his bastard armes her to embrace.
And I (said Braggadocchio) thought no lesse,
To punish: yet it better first I thought,
His wandring thought in deepe desire does steepe,
Withdraw from thought of warlike enterprize,
Did feed his eyes, and fild his inner thought.
Some thought to raise themselues to high degree,
Against the Pagans brest, and therewith thought
More glory thought to giue life, then decay,
Not wrought, nor pourtrahed, but easie to be thought.
As if some pensiue thought co[n]straind her gentle spright.
By Phoebus doome, the wisest thought aliue,
And all that in the world was aye thought wittily.
But was all desolate, and of some thought
Those yet of her be Mertia[n] lawes both nam'd & thought.
Disguised slaine, ere any thereof thought:
And her attaching, thought her hands to tye;
Reuiuing thought of glorie and of fame,
Then thought the Prince all perill sure was past,
No sooner thought, then that the Carle as fast
And thought his labour lost and trauell vaine,
Thought to haue mounted, but his feeble vaines
One would haue thought, (so cunningly, the rude,
Should euer enter in his bounteous thought,
That may vnworthy of it selfe be thought.
So thought this Mayd (as maydens vse to done)
Yet thought it was not loue, but some melancholy.
So thought she to vndoe her daughters loue:
Or th'Indian Peru he were, she thought
And thought so to beguile her grieuous smart;
Tho full of bitter griefe and pensiue thought,
To her no euill thought, nor euill deed;
In his free thought to build her sluggish nest:
Ne suffereth it thought of vngentlenesse,
Prouidence heauenly passeth liuing thought,
That suddein change she strange aduenture thought.
Perforce her carried, where euer he thought best.
To which the Damzell full of doubtfull thought,
And thought her to adore with humble spright;
And his base thought with terrour and with aw
His caytiue thought durst not so high aspire,
And by her deuilish arts thought to preuaile,
These twinnes, men say, (a thing far passing thought)
Thought with that sight him much to haue reliued;
He surely dempt, himselfe he thought depriued
With thought whereof, exceeding mad he grew,
Who seeing her gan streight vpstart, and thought
And thought that match a fowle disparagement:
He marueild more, and thought he yet did dreame
She thought, but chaung'd from one to other feare;
Sorely thereat he was displeasd, and thought
Which th'old man seeing well, who too long thought
Ten thousand wayes he cast in his confused thought.
But through long anguish, and selfe-murdring thought
Yet thought himselfe not safe enough thereby,
It vaine she thought with rigorous vprore
The which he thought, for villeinous despight,
Had ye them seene, ye would haue surely thought,
His will she feard; for him she surely thought
Some thought that some enchantment faygned it;
For all her studie was and all her thought,
Which when he thought, it grieued him full sore,
To calme the tempest of his troubled thought:
That though therein himselfe he thought to pas,
Whose beautie each of them thought excellent,
But Braggadochio said, he neuer thought
Ne was there Knight that euer thought of armes,
And thought in mind it shortly to amend:
For pearelesse she was thought, that did it beare.
But inly thought of that despightfull deede
Assembled in one place: ne he that thought
Till Blandamour, who thought he had the trew
Yet thought that Florimell was not so faire as shee.
They thought to gird, as best it her became;
And each one thought, as to their fancies came.
But when they thought it fast, eftsoones it was vntide.
And thought t'appeale from that, which was decreed,
Some thought from him her to haue reft by might;
Yet not fit place he thought it there to stay,
And thought his wearie limbs to haue redrest.
As if he thought her soule to disentrayle.
She arm'd her tongue, and thought at him to scold;
Hath troubled both your mindes with idle thought,
But thought she wandred was, or gone astray.
For in that place where I him thought to find,
There was I found, contrary to my thought,
That in her wrath she thought them both haue thrild,
She follow'd her, and thought againe it to assay.
Whose looser thought will lightly be misled,
Vnto his bay, and captiued her thought.
Being likewise beguiled in her thought,
I boldly thought (so young mens thoughts are bold)
Caught hold on me, and thought my steps to stay,
I thought there was none other heauen then this;
He thought her to compell by crueltie and awe.
But thought it all one night, that did no houres diuide.
Some while he thought, by faire and humble wise
The thought whereof empierst his hart so deepe,
Most did she thinke, but most she thought amis,
If ought lay hidden in his grieued thought,
That he did languish of some inward thought,
For loue of Nymphes she thought she need not care,
To Proteus selfe to sew she thought it vaine,
For neuer wight so euill did or thought,
A knight (said he) if knight he may be thought,
Vnmou'd with praiers, or with piteous thought,
Or weigh the thought, that fro[m] mans mind doth flow.
Which as our owne we tooke, and so it thought.
The worke of heauens will surpasseth humaine thought.
Whom she thought fittest for that businesse,
But when they thought on Talus hands to lay,
To reskew his owne Lord, but thought it iust t'obay.
Scarse so conceiued in her iealous thought,
She thought to send some one to seeke him out;
In euery place, and euery place thought best,
But still right downe, and in her thought did hide
Her minde was whole possessed of one thought,
But thought, that she thereon could neuer gaze her fill.
Mote in them stirre vp old rebellious thought,
She much was eased in her troublous thought,
She was confused in her troublous thought,
Thought with his speare him quight haue ouerwent.
Which my liege Lady seeing, thought it best,
So thought the Souldan in his follies threat,
As a faire stoupe of her high soaring thought,
